pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:0.4: 6. The training rule on building huts
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.2: At that time the monks of Āḷavī were building huts by means of begging. The huts were intended for themselves, did not have a sponsoring owner, and were inappropriate in size.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.4: and so the monks kept on asking and begging,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.5: “Give a man, give a servant, give an ox, give a cart, give a machete, give a hatchet, give an axe, give a spade, give a chisel, give a creeper, give bamboo, give reed, give grass, give clay.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.6: People felt oppressed by all the asking and begging, so much so that when they saw a monk they became alarmed and fearful, and they ran away, took a different path, turned away, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.7: They even ran away when they saw cows, thinking they were monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.8: Just then Venerable Mahākassapa, after spending the rainy season at Rājagaha, set out for Āḷavī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.9: When he eventually arrived in Āḷavī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.10: he stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.11: In the morning Venerable Mahākassapa robed up, took his bowl and robe, and entered Āḷavī for alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.12: When people saw him they became fearful and alarmed, and they ran away, took a different path, turned away, and closed their doors.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.13: After finishing his almsround and eating his meal, Venerable Mahākassapa returned and said to the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.14: “Āḷavī used to have plenty of food, and it wasn’t difficult to get by on almsfood.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.15: But now Āḷavī is short of almsfood, and it’s not easy to get by on alms.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.1.17: The monks told Venerable Mahākassapa what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.1: Around the same time, after staying at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, the Master too set out for Āḷavī.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.2: When he eventually arrived at Āḷavī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.3: he too stayed at the Aggāḷava Shrine.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.5: bowed down to him, and sat down to one side.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.6: And he told the Master what had happened.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.7: The Master then had the Order of monks assembled and questioned the monks of Āḷavī,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.8: “Is it true, monks, that you are building huts through begging, huts intended for yourself, without a sponsoring owner, and inappropriate in size?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.9: And that because they were never completed,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.10: you kept on asking and begging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.12: and people felt oppressed to point where they now avoid monks?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.15: Foolish men, how can you act like this?
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.19: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it …”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.2.20: After rebuking them, he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.1: “Once upon a time, monks, two sages who were brothers lived near the river Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.2: On one occasion the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.3: He encircled him with seven coils and spread his large hood over his head.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.4: Because of his fear of that dragon, the younger sage became thin, haggard, and pale, his veins protruding all over his limbs.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.5: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.6: and asked him what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.8: And the younger sage told him.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.11: The elder sage said, ‘Would you like that dragon not to return?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.13: ‘Well then, did you see anything belonging to that dragon?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.14: ‘I saw an ornamental jewel on his neck.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.15: ‘In that case ask the dragon for that jewel.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.18: Soon the dragon king again emerged from the Ganges, approached the younger sage,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.24: ‘The monk is asking for the jewel,’ and he quickly departed.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.25: Once more the dragon king emerged from the Ganges and approached the younger sage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.32: Yet again the dragon king emerged from the Ganges.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.33: The younger sage saw him emerging
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.37: The dragon king then spoke these verses to the sage:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.38: ‘My food and drink are abundant and sublime,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.39: And they appear because of this jewel.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.40: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.41: Nor will I return to your hermitage.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.42: Like a boy holding a sharp sword,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.43: You frighten me, asking for this stone.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.44: I won’t give it to you—you ask too much,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.45: Nor will I return to your hermitage.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.46: And the dragon king Maṇikaṇṭha thought,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.47: ‘The monk is asking for the jewel; he wants the jewel,’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.48: and he departed and never returned.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.49: Because he did not get to see that beautiful dragon, the young sage became even thinner, more haggard and pale, his veins protruding even more.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.50: The older sage saw him like this
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.51: and asked what was the matter.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.53: He replied, ‘It’s because I no longer get to see that beautiful dragon.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.54: The older sage then spoke to him in verse:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.55: ‘One should not beg from those one wishes to be dear to;
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.56: One is detested for asking for too much.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.57: When the brahmin asked the dragon for his jewel,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.58: It departed and was never to be seen again.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.3.59: One will be disliked even by animals, monks, for asking and begging,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.1: “At one time, monks, a certain monk lived in a forest grove on the slopes of the Himalayas.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.2: Not far from that grove was an large, low-lying marsh.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.3: A great flock of birds fed in the marsh during the day and entered the grove to roost at night.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.4: The monk was disturbed by the noise of the flocking birds, and so he came to see me.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.5: He bowed down to me, sat down to one side,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.7: ‘I hope you’re keeping well, monk; I hope you’re comfortable. I hope you’re not tired from traveling.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.11: And I’m not tired from traveling.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.12: On the slopes of the Himalayas there’s a great forest grove
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.13: and close by a large low-lying marsh.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.14: A large flock of birds feeds in that low-lying marsh during the day and comes at night to roost in that forest grove.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.15: That’s where I’ve come from, Master,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.16: and I left because I was disturbed by the noise of that flock of birds.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.17: ‘Would you like that flock of birds not to return?’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.19: ‘Well then, go back to that forest grove. In the first part of the night, call out three times,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.21: From whoever roosts in this forest grove, I want a feather.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.22: Each one of you must give me a feather.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.24: and third part of the night do the same thing.’
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.4.28: The monk returned to that forest grove and did as instructed.

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.5: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.6: ‘When a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for himself,
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.7: it is to be no more than 3 meters long and 1.75 meters wide inside.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.8: He must get monks to approve a site
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.9: where no harm will be done
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.10: and which has a space on all sides.
pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:1.6.11: If a monk, by means of begging, builds a hut on a site where harm will be done and which lacks a space on all sides, or he does not get monks to approve the site, or he exceeds the size limit, he commits an offense entailing suspension.’”

pli-tv-bu-vb-ss6:2.2.3: “Venerables, I wish, by means of begging, to build a hut without a sponsoring owner and intended for myself.
